chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the returns based on the nominal rate and the real rate of return.

**a.** Face value refers to the actual value paid to the owner of the bond when the bond reaches its maturity. 

In this problem, we are tasked to solve for the total dollar return of the investment. The **total dollar return** refers to the sum of the capital gain and the dividend income. The **capital gain** is the difference between the initial and final price of the bond.

The dividend income can simply be solved by multiplying the coupon rate to the face value or the initial price of the bond in this case. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend income}&=\$1,000 \times 0.07\\
&=\$70
\end{aligned}$$

The dividend income for this case is $\$70$.

Now that we have the values, we can solve for the total dollar return:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total dollar return}&=\$70+(\$985-\$1,010)\\
&=\$45
\end{aligned}$$

The total dollar return in this investment is $\$45$.

**b.** The nominal rate refers to the percentage of the initial price that is given as the dollar return. This can be solved by dividing the total dollar return by the initial price. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Nominal rate of return}&=\dfrac{\$45}{\$1,010}\\
&=0.0446
\end{aligned}$$

The nominal rate of return on this investment is $0.0446$ or $4.46\%$

**c.** The real rate of return refers to the rate of return with respect to the inflation rate. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real rate of return}&=\dfrac{1+\text{Nominal rate of return}}{1+\text{Inflation rate}}-1\\
&=\dfrac{1+0.0446}{1+0.03}-1\\
&=0.0142
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the rate of return, considering the inflation rate, is $0.0142$ or $1.42\%$.
